description.narrative:
Sverige har bidragit till Rwandas nationella sysselsättningsprogram, National Employment Programme (NEP), med 98 577 225 miljoner kronor under de tre första programåren, juli 2014 - juni 2017 och planerar nu stöd till de kvarvarande programåren, juli 2017 - juni 2019, med 62 422 775 miljoner kronor.
Programmet syftar till att:
1. Skapa produktiva arbetstillfällen utanför jordbruket (off-farm jobs). 2. Utrusta Rwandas arbetskraft med nödvändig kunskap för ökad produktivitet. 3. Skapa ett koordinerat och sammanhållet ramverk för alla offentliga sysselsättningskapande åtgärder.
NEP adresserar således en av Rwandas största utvecklingsutmaningar, att skapa tillräckligt många produktiva arbetstillfällen, det vill säga arbete som generar tillräcklig inkomst för den som arbetar att försörja sin familj och ta sig ur fattigdom. Programmet är landsomfattande och involverar flera ministerier och myndigheter på central och lokal nivå.

Sweden has funded Rwanda’s National Employment Programme (NEP) with 98 577 225 SEK over three years, July 2014 - June 2017, and is planning for a second phase of funding with 62 422 775 SEK covering the two remaining years of the programme period, July 2017 - June 2019. The National Employment Programme is a government programme aiming at:
1.Creating sufficient productive off-farm jobs 2.Equipping the workforce with vital skills for increased productivity 3.Providing a national framework for coordinating all employment promotion initiatives
As such, the purpose of NEP is to address one of Rwanda’s main development challenges, namely to create sufficient productive employment opportunities, i.e. yielding enough income to allow the worker and his/her family/dependents a living standard above the poverty line.

Sweden is funding Rwanda’s National Employment Programme (NEP) with 160 million SEK over five years, 2014 – 2019. The funding has been subject to two sequential agreements, i.e. 100 million SEK for three fiscal years 2014-2017 and 60 million SEK for two fiscal years 2017-2019. The National Employment Programme is a government programme aiming at: 1.Creating sufficient productive off-farm jobs 2.Equipping the workforce with vital skills for increased productivity 3.Providing a national framework for coordinating all employment promotion initiatives As such, the purpose of NEP is to address one of Rwanda’s main development challenges, namely to create sufficient productive employment opportunities, i.e. yielding enough income to allow the worker and his/her family/dependents a living standard above the poverty line.

participating-org.narrative: Sida administrative activity implemented by procured partner

tag.narrative: 4.3 - By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.
4.3 - Senast 2030 säkerställa alla kvinnor och män lika tillgång till yrkesutbildning och eftergymnasial utbildning, inklusive högskoleutbildning, av god kvalitet till en överkomlig kostnad.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.

description.narrative: Summary of results This conclusion on performance is for handover but builds on the annual conclusion on performance from August 2018. After fiscal year 2016/2017, Rwanda's Local Development Agency, LODA, estimated the total annual number of off-farm jobs created to 233,190. This is over 30,000 more new jobs than expected. NEP activities are estimated to have created 46,206 off-farm jobs in the fiscal year of 2016/2017. This is 17,658, or 61.8%, more than the expected annual target of 28,548 off-farm jobs. This means that NEP contributes almost 20% to the total estimated number of created off-farm jobs. As regards, progress for fiscal year 2017/2018, here is a summary of achievements for each pillar of NEP. Pillar I Skills development and employabilityThe overall performance of Pillar I was not as good as expected and compared to the previous fiscal years. Some of the interventions such as recognition of prior learning, reconversion programme and internship programme reached or almost reached the targets whereas massive vocational training, rapid responsive training and industrial based training only reached around 50 percent of target. The low performance isattributed to the fact that the Skills Development Fund (Under Priority Skills for Growth project financed by World Bank) targets were combined with the already existing NEP targets under different pillar I interventions. During the last two quarters of the fiscal year, training gained some momentum and caught up with the very low performance of the first two quarters. Pillar II Entrepreneurship and BDS support to MSMEsThe overall performance of pillar II interventions were overall more satisfactory where key interventions such as business plans and business development coaching achieved 113 percent of the target. Loans for start-up tool kits and loans for self-employed MSMEs were at 70 and 80 percent respectively. Pillar III Employment opportunities for vulnerable householdsOver 100,000 members of the poor households benefited from public works under VUP, which represents 85% of the annual target. In addition, 43,889 youth and women were mobilised to benefit from NEP Opportunities. Pillar IV Coordination, monitoring and evaluationThe NEP Secretariat implemented several coordination sessions and meetings with NEP key implementing partners with a focus on professionalisation of Business Development Services (BDAs) and formation of their cooperatives at district level. This follows a recommendation of the mid-term NEP evaluation by Sweden, that highlighted the need to strengthen capacities and organisation of the BDAs as well as to form an accreditation system. These initiatives were discussed with RDB and MINICOM and in early 2018, meetings with BDAs were held for them to take ownership of the processes and steps in the accreditation process. NEP also conducted an evaluation of the BDAs to assess the extent of their capacities to deliver business advisory services. This evaluation also came as pre-accreditation step that will pave way for the whole BDA accreditation. Planning of the annual review and planning sessions with all NEP implementing partners were held in early 2018. The focus was to strengthen M&E and further linking pillar I and II, i.e. linking skills development beneficiaries to the start-up/business support, thereby creating a clearer pathway to employment for youth and women.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
